My review in 4 words: This game is awesome!
Stunning graphics great gameplay. Finally a shooter with a good story!
This game is not just a shooter because you have cool powers named vigors, and you can hang on transport rails for a cool rollercoaster effect while shooting robotic monsters. And in this game the person which you escort is not a brainless moron FINALLY!

Questa volta è una recensione davvero difficile quella che mi accingo a fare. Recensire un gioco come Bioshock Infinite ed essere chiari ed esastivi non è certo una cosa facile, dato la beltà del capitolo d'origine. Ci proverò comunque. 
Bioshock Infinte è, come dissi anche per Portal 2, vera e propria arte videoludica.
Ci troviamo stavolta a Columbia, una surreale e utopica città volante gestita da un certo Padre Comstok, un estremista e antisemita republicano. Il compito del portagonista è quello di recuperare una ragazza e riportarla a New York per annulare un debito di gioco con un fantomatico creditore.
Il titolo offre una delle sceneggiature più intense ed articolate mai viste in videogioco, la quale viene supportata dal gameplay  classico della serie, quindi una garanzia per tutti gli amanti della saga.
Il comparto tecnico è di grande fattura, così come la qualità delle scelte artistiche di Columbia, che incanta il giocatore, trasportandolo nell'epoca dei primi anni del 900 americano
In conclusione posso dire di avere giocato al degno erede del primo Bioshock, il quale riesce in più di qualche circostanza, ad essere superiore al suo glorioso predecessore. Estrememante consigliato

Awesome!

It is my opinion that this game is one of the most overrated games out there, together with the Uncharted series and Fallout 3. Environments looks beautiful and rich with detail, sound design is also commendable. The actual GAMEPLAY and story is lackluster to say the least. 

The gameplay doesn't really improve upon the first two Bioshock games. Two guns only, plasmids are back for some reason, standard stuff. Nothing mindblowing and really worth talking about at length. The constant "ambushed" gunplay scenarios do get a bit boring after a while. 

The plot is the most lauded feature of this game, most reviewers can't stop talking about it. I'm all for sweeping and engaging storylines that make you want to finish the game to see how it all ends, but.. everything the game sets up toward the finale comes crumbling down in what is probably the most painfully obvious plothole ridden hyper pretentious ending I have ever encountered. It just does not make any sense.

This is the last time I get hyped over a game like this. Mind you, I played Bioshock 1 multiple times because I was trying very hard to 'get' why people call it a masterpiece. I thought I was playing the game wrong, I wasn't.

Don't think I hate this game, I had decent fun while playing. It is certainly not a bad game. You might adore this game or not, it depends. Give it a shot at least during a winter/summer/halloween/thanksgibing sale if you're really curious
It's pretty like Grandma when she was pretty in 1910.

Let's get my biases out of the way first: I am a fan of System Shock 2 as well as a fan of Bioshock 1. I hated Bioshock 2 for being a pointless sequel to a game that didn't need a sequel, and I was sceptical of Infinite when I started it.

So, Bioshock Infinite, then.

To get the obvious out of the way, this game looks and sounds AMAZING. The visuals alone are well above par, the animation for the chatacters, the level of environmental detail and all of the special effects are top-notch. If you are looking for a pretty game, this is definitely one.

However, there is a but: the story of the game, the characters (especially the protagonist) and the premise of the game itself are illogical and, to be blunt, stupid as hell. To give you an example from very early in the game: posters are depicting a "false shepherd" as an evil to be rooted and destroyed on sight, and this false shepherd is identified by a tattoo on the hand of the shepherd. The protagonist has an identical tattoo to the images, and remarks on this. However, it never crosses his mind to cover the tattoo up or hide it. There are dozens of situations like these in which I could see a trap coming miles away, but the story demanded that I play my part oblivious to the signs, which is incredibly annoying.

Add to this the fact that the story is a convoluted mess with very little sense to be had in any of the character's motivations and reasons, and you might find yourself disliking the game for it's story as much as I did.

The gameplay could be called "standard" nowadays. The skyrails are a cool little system, but they are poorly utilized in gameplay, as are the rifts that allow you to spawn objects into the game. As a matter of fact, I found myself accidentally materializing objects while trying to fight enemies, so these opportunities have a bad habit of becoming hindrances during fights.

Oh, the fights? Enemies come your way and you shoot them. I played  through 90% of the game with the sniper rifle and the carbine, and almost never found myself needing other weapons. There are several special powers (tonics) for you to use, but most of these are simply callbacks to the Bioshock games and serve no true in-game purpose in Infinite. (In fact, the tonics are a pretty big inconsistency in the game's story for most of the time)

All in all, if you can look past the dumb characters, convoluted plot and pretty basic gameplay with surprisingly little freedom, you might enjoy Infinite. I have to admit I sure didn't.

Playtime: 10+ hours (single playthrough)

Ratings (1-10)
Visual: 10
Audio: 10
Story: 4
Gameplay: 6
Overall: 8

This game was nothing short of brilliant. Even days after completing it, I'm finding my mind coming back and dwelling on parts of the story.

Story and graphics were 10/10. If you nitpick you may find some details in the story that don't line up, but it's a form of entertainment, not an historical account of soemthing, so give it breathing space.

I'd imagine you could get a few playthroughs from it, if only to pickup on foreshadowing early on in the game.

I played through at a relatively leisurely pace (read as: I picked up everything I could find and tracked down as much as I could) and completed it in just shy of 17 hours.

But still, all in all, awesome game.

Can't believe how much friggin' HD space it all took (19 GB, 5 GB larger than the main game!!!) but certainly worth it for the whole story/experience.

I went into this with high expectations from what I've heard.  The visual design, the story, the graphics, the soundtrack, dialogue/voice acting, the atmosphere are all 10/10.  As a cinematic experience, it's unforgettable and top notch.  When I started playing it, I remember reading that a lot of people saw the game as a huge anti-Mormon/LDS experience & that came back.  The game takes place in 1912, in the floating city of Columbia.  Post Civil War America is a growing super power, heavy themes of racism, worker oppression, big business, anti-foreigner & religious revivalism are going on with some elements of Greek mythology like the first 2 Bioshocks.  The main villain is 1/2 Joseph Smith & 1/2 Brigham Young.

The actual gameplay is solid, nothing spectacular or amazing.  I played through on 1999 mode and barely used the vigors which is supposed to be a big draw in the Bioshock world.  I used Shock Jockey for stun, but everything else is basically worthless.  Then you get to the final boss fight & HAVE to use a lot of vigors, so my build made it really hard.  I like the damage numbers & critical strikes popping up on enemies like in Borderlands to see how much HP they have though.  1999 mode wasn't really that hard except for about 2 parts.  There is a recycled boss fight 3 times and a lot of Handyman (read: Big Daddy) fights, the gameplay didn't innovate much and was as long as it was for the sake of story, not because they had that many gameplay ideas.

For the Season Pass, Clash in the Clouds is just a boring challenge map DLC.  It's just waves of enemies & blue ribbon challenges.  Only play it if you care about achievements.  Burial at Sea is a 2 hour story campaign that ties into the main game, but takes you to 1958 Rapture, just before the events of Bioshock 1.  It actually adds a lot to the story & is very worth playing.  As of now, I know they're coming out with Burial at Sea part 2, but I don't know if anything else is coming for it or not.

Of the 3 Bioshocks, Infinite definitely has the best story & art design, but Bioshock 2 was the most fun for me.  I can appreciate Infinite tying into the previous stories in a unique way & the DLC adds to the story more.

Final Verdict: 8.5/10  Definitely worth playing through, but just a bit over rated for average gameplay.

"Bioshock Infinite è una bella storia da giocare prima di andare a letto." 
(cit. Keyazzo)

__________________________________________________________________

Il terzo capitolo della saga cambia location. Abbandonate scafandro e abissi marini e gettatevi liberi e affascinati nel cielo di Columbia, una delle città virtuali più belle mai costruite. 
Impersonerete Booker DeWitt, carismatico protagonista assoldato da chissà chi per salvare una ragazza.
Ho deciso di organizzare in punti la recensione del titolo, per rendere più semplice l'analisi del tutto, enfatizzando i vari clichè onnipresenti nei videogame: GAMEPLAY-STORIA-GRAFICA-AUDIO-LONGEVITA', quindi iniziamo.

GAMEPLAY
Il gameplay, il cavallo di battaglia della serie, non delude neanche in questo episodio. Un misto di FPS e GDR con possibilità di utilizzare i Vigor (poteri) e le armi con il semplice uso dei tasti destro e sinistro del mouse, gestione di upgrade sia delle armi che dei poteri la fanno, come sempe, da padroni con l'aggiunta del vestiario (piccoli oggetti sparsi per i mondi sotto forma di pacco) che danno bonus permanenti su testa, corpo, gambe e scarpe, come ogni gdr che si rispetti proprone.
Intelligenza artificiale abbastanza nella norma, con nemici che, purtroppo a volte si buttano un pò troppo in mezzo alla ressa senza curarsi della propria incolumità. Comunque sia a livello difficile la sfida è ben alta e a meno di non essersi equipaggiati per bene, con pochi colpi messi a segno, giacerete per terra in una pozza di sangue.
Possibilità nel gioco di compiere delle scelte, se influenzeranno o meno il gioco sta a voi scoprirlo.

STORIA
Una storia ricca di temi e significati. Religione, razzismo, patriottismo e fisica teorica sono solo alcuni dei temi trattati nella storia, ove senza svelare nulla, Booker si ritroverà a dover rintracciare una ragazza del nome Elisabeth.
Per il resto, ogni parola sarebbe spoiler, quindi giocatevelo voi! L'unico mio consiglio è di giocarlo con calma. Ispezionate ogni anfratto, ascoltate ogni dialogo, darete quella marcia in più alla godibilità del titolo. 
Come si dice? La storia è importante.

GRAFICA
Il gioco sprizza maestosità da ogni pixel! Un'opera d'arte su monitor, a meno che si possa usufruire del pieno comparto grafico, grazie alle ultime, potenti, schede video su mercato, anche se tecnicamente un pò arretrata.
Curato sotto ogni piccolo particolare, Bioshock Infinite vi metterà davanti a una città curata e viva, con la possibilità di goderne appieno grazie alle opzioni video adeguatamente scalabili. 
C'è da dire che l'Unreal Engine ha permesso di uniformare la grafica del titolo su diverse piattaforme, facendo probavilmente abbassare lo standard per la versione pc, che resta comunque estremamente elevato e piacevole.
Ad alcuni potrebbe non piacere lo stile "fumettoso" dei personaggi, ma essendo uno stile riproposto ben da 3 capitoli del gioco da Irrational Games non credo ci siano problemi alcuni.

AUDIO
Il comparto audio è molto curato, con una delle colonne sonore più suggestive che abbia ultimamente udito in un viodeogame. Non discostandosi dal canone qualitativo della serie, forse addirittura superandolo, Bioshock Infinite propone un variegato e magnifico insieme di brani di diverse tipologie, dal ghospel da chiesa americana, a grandi brani dell'epoca.
Molto ben recitato anche il doppiaggio italiano che si fa ben apprezzare.

LONGEVITA'
Il gioco si aggira intorno alle 8 ore di gioco a livello difficile, gustandolo in ogni piccolo particolare e cercando ogni oggetto in ogni angolo sperduto dei livelli.
__________________________________________________________________

PRO
-Trama convolgente e ben studiata
- Level design e città di Columbia affascinanti 
- Location diversa che stacca un pò dall'onnipresente mare dei primi due

CONTRO
- Graficamente appagante ma tecnicamente datato
- A volte dispersivo se non preso con la dovuta "calma"
- Nemici a volte ancora troppo stupidi

__________________________________________________________________

Un gioco da avere assolutamente nella propria collezione, giocatelo, divertitevi e fermatevi a ragionare su quello che questa storia ha da insegnarvi. 

Sta a voi poi imparare.

As a newcomer to the BioShock series of games, my expectations weren't exactly meteroic for this game. Based on what I'd heard of the series, I was expecting a quirky first person shooter with some intersting mechanics and a 'spellcasting' system. 

This is prettyy much what I got. The combat is fluid and mostly fun - a little repetitive towards the end as the game seems to be trying to avoid the old Half-Life paradigm of 'the guns you get at the end of the best', so you end up using essentially the same gear througout. So far, so 'meh, it was on sale anyway'.

But what I also got was one of the best and most affecting plots that's I've come across in a very, very long time. It contrives to effortlessly lead you to invest emotionally in the young girl that you're escorting through the nightmare of religious zealotry that is Columbia - Elizabeth. Elizabeth is what makes the game, for me. Wonderfully voiced and presented, her character is developed over the course of the game as she goes from being the means to the end to being the end itself. She's also (unusually for a FPS sidekick) really handy in a fight. Not that she does any fighting - she tends to hide at the first signs of gunfire. Rather she throws ammo, health and other supplies to you at critical junctures. No more escort mission nonsense here.

The story is beautifully told and, unusually for a FPS, the player is not entirely the protagonist. As you delve deeper into the plot (and your own character's past), you realise that the writers behind BioShock: Infinite have had the courage to tackle an intellectually demanding narrative - there are guides on the internet which seek to explain the meaning behind the final scene. People need diagrams and timelines to do this, I kid ye not.

The main story left me thoughtful - I needed to sit for a while and think about what had just happened: not just to work out what had just happened but also to come to terms emotionally with what the game had just put me through. I haven't had that kind of reaction to video game writing in a seriously long time. 

If ever you get told that "first person shooters" are for stupid people - play this game. In fact, just play it anyway - you won't regret it.

I have to say I was pleasantly surprised about nearly every aspect of this game. You instantly find youself at home in very steampunk, 1912 sky city that is absolutely gorgeous. I run a pretty sorry rig with 4 gb of ram and 512 VRAM but was still able to play with no lag once I toned down the graphics settings. Even with dummed down visuals, the experience as a whole is still breathtaking. I would reccommend this game to anyone looking for a good story in an innovative first person shooter. This game builds even further on the mechanics established in Bioshocks one and two without the player needing any knowledge about them. New mechanics that seem gimicks at first will shock you in how well they're implimented. I will suck up tothis game even more based on the fact that it is doing incredibly well in what a lot of other shooters today are failing miserably at. Innovation. In 2007 Bioshock rattled the standers for shooters with the introduction of plasmids and gene tonics. Infinite takes it another step further with weapons that can be upgraded more frequently and different types of upgrades all together. The characters in this game are yet another point that meets all expectations. Booker DeWitt, Elizibeth, and all others are very misterious and if nothing else compells you to finish the game, these characters will. In conclusion, I would reccommend this game to anyone looking for something refreshing. Very little competition for a story and gameplay combo like this. Every bit worth the purchase
Great game with an engaging plot and fantastic playability

Bioshock Infinite isn't a bad game, but its various game systems don't mesh with the interactive environment as completely as they did in the first Bioshock, or System Shock 2. The focus of this game is on spectacle and social commentary. These components are done very well, but even in their best moments, I found myself missing what made the two other respected "shock" titles so special. In Bioshock Infinite you are not apart of a living breathing world, you are a tourist in an extremely unnerving portrait of historical american society.
The most pretty-goodest game I ever played.
This game is cool, but get it on sale.  It's pretty short and the gameplay isn't great, but its good to look at and has an interesting story.

Its BioShock in a new setting; if you were cool with BioShock being System Shock in a new setting, you'll probably be mostly cool with this.  The gameplay is largely unchanged, handful of new mechanics, all of which seem to work as intended. I can't think of any logical complaints, except the save system, no manual saves or quicksaves, only ONE autosave.  I bloody hate that, even if it doesn't really matter with how they designed the game; but that aside, really enjoying my time with it.

Rapture is still more interesting to me, but I think that will largely come down to personal preference; I'll refrain from saying how or why Columbia can be as interesting as Rapture, but if you liked BioShock for any reason, you'll most likely enjoy this game, hell its almost an homage to the first game in fact. If you didn't enjoy BioShock, this game probably won't do you any favors.

Also, play it on hard unless you just want to drink in the story.  Seriously, I did, and I only had trouble with a couple fights, and I'm not badass or anything, in fact I had a bad habit of bringing the wrong guns to the wrong fights, and I managed okay for the most part - the last real battle took me 4 tries, and when I got there I was low on every kinda ammo except guns I hated. And, for what its worth, don't invest too much into any one power or gun until you're halfway into the game, you'll find out why.
Yep
Very cool and fun game. A nice, yet messed up story :(

Bioshock Infinite is art. If it is not, then do not know what could be. The graphics, the neoclassical architecture consistent with the 1912 period, the music and its performance, the joke with music and tears where you could see part of a past future and how all this is presented in the game is sublime. And moreover, remains a game with plenty of action, with the player in control. Just do not give a score of 10 because of some bugs, like what happened once, preventing an scripted event from happening and to progress in the game, and the way everything is solved with violence.

Bought it on the Thanksgiving Sale. The game offers a good story line and it's worth it to explore every possible side area. I missed a few things so I may reload a few levels to see what else I can find.

The DLCs interest me. I'llw wait for the Christmas sale to get those. :)

This Is One Of The Best Games Of All Time! The storyline is the best storyline that I have ever seen. The Graphics In The Game Are Fantastic. This Game has some off the best voice acters that a video game could have. I would strongly recummend that you get this game!
Another good chapter in the Bioshock family.  Ending is very interesting.

An excellent game, though not as enjoyable story-wise as BioShock 1 or its distant ancestor, System Shock 2.

The gameplay is fun, but the story felt a bit forced, like you're being dragged through a hurricane.

That being said, this is still one of the best games of 2013.

At the moment i have played Both Bioshock 2 and Bioshock infinte. I liked everything about bioshock 2 But i hated how short the game was , I liked bioshock infinte as well but i felt it wasnt as good as bioshock 2 . people had said the game had brilliant graphics and it was a beautiful game but when i played it i noticed loads of things that looked bad like the other parts of columbia that you could see in the distance were only 2d floating buildings and the fact that if you shot at a group of bottles they would all brake and smash.All together i think this is an alright game for people that dont really like looking at the art of things but like the other parts of games.

So in my opinion I'd give Bioshock Infinte a 7.5 / 10 

I have yet to play bioshock 1 as i have heard lots of many good things about it and i have seen bits of gameplay of it.
One of many ways how 2013 went out with a bang. An awesome story teller for a game!
This game has an awesome storyline. Will not disappoint.
Amazing game, great combination of science fiction, steampunk, art deco and shooting. Excellent style, intriguing plot, impressive ending... What are you waiting for? Just buy and try it!

Holy crap.. If you aren't a fan of the Bioshock Series, this will definitely change your mind.. The game is beautiful, challenging, intriguing... It messes with your mind and you won't see any of it coming until the very last minute of the game. You HAVE to play it until the end. I loved the game so much and I seriously could not put the game down..

9.5/10, being my most critical review.. There were minor bugs that I wouldn't mind seeing fixed but thid game is just beautifully made... I am so glad I played it. It really makes you think! Thank you!

I have to say three good things about Bioshock Infinite: it's visually gorgeous, it's very clever in terms of ambient storytelling and Elizabeth is a great charachter. But that's it... there's not a lot to say about the rest: the relation with Elizabeth was the only reason I finished the game. Problem is: just like the rest of the series, the good aspects are only  a nice dress for a linear shooting experience. Story and gameplay don't even try to reconcile and there's nothing substantial about the backstory and its "philosophy". It's just a convoluted excuse to blow heads off with guns and magic: the gameplay has been dumbed down for the casual crowd when compared to Bioshock 1 & 2. There's no survival or rpg-lite element. Just... shooting. The story does not make any kind of sense, but that's a given for the Bioshock series. Overall, Infinite is one of the most overrated game I ever played. 

Vote: 5,5
I usually do not play offline games at all. Im very hard to entertain and I have to say this is the best campaign and story I've ever played in my life.
Bioshock Infinite is a prime example that games can be an art form with great visuals, an engrossing story that tackles very complex themes all wrapped up with a competent but very fun combat sistem.
Best game I've ever played!

Quite possible the best game i have ever played. Not many video games are up to the task of conquering Quantum Physics. The story will keep you engaged from start to finish and you will feel apart of a ever changing story with plot twists blowing out your ears. i was on the edge of my seat the whole time. if your on the edge and your reading this? Trust me, you wont be disapointed.

Ce jeu est tout simplement une pure merveille ! Un monstre graphique, une ambiance géniale et une bonne durée de vie, tout ceci associé à un scénario à couper le souffle.
Je le recommande vivement !

I dont see why they cant follow up with a System Shock AR if they can make a bioshock-DLC. Sparked my interrest to finish Bioshock 2. Looks very nice, handles.. meh, pretty decently. I best enjoyed it when i didint find ammo all over the darn place tho. 

Oh, i recommend the Starting pistol (Luger) and the Carbine. Dont get me wrong, the sniper-rifle is good, but it just dosent have enough ammo to be worth toting around.
